text: This case report is for a 70-year-old male.
The patient was referred to our hospital with a chief complaint of hemoptysis, and was diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer based on the findings of the CT scan and bronchoscopy.
Then, while durvalumab (anti-PD-L1 antibody) was dosed as maintenance therapy for two courses of radiochemotherapy (S-1 + CDDP), we observed fever and increased inflammatory response.
Thus, LVFX was started 5 days after anti-PD-L1 antibody therapy was started.
After the third dose of LVFX, the blood work showed a further increase in the level of hepatic dysfunction coupled with an inflammatory response.
It was decided to order a contrast enhanced computed tomography (CECT).
It revealed multiple small, poorly contrast enhanced masses in the hepatic region inside the radiated area by the radiotherapy that had been given for the treatment of the lung cancer.

entities.name: hepatic region inside the radiated area

text: We suspected multiple liver abscesses or multiple liver metastases of the lung cancer, and performed a liver tumor biopsy.

entities.name: multiple liver abscesses or multiple liver metastases of the lung cancer

text: Histopathological findings showed scattered hepatocellular necrosis, which was thought to be coagulation necrosis, but there was no obvious sign of invasion of the lung cancer into the liver.

entities.name: hepatocellular necrosis, which was thought to be coagulation necrosis
invasion of the lung cancer into the liver

text: A blood culture was also taken, but no bacteria were found.

Based on the results, we concluded that the patient had multiple hepatic masses due to inflammation, and the original course of antibiotics was continued; the patient's inflammatory response improved one week after starting dosage of the antibiotics.

entities.name: multiple hepatic masses due to inflammation

text: However, an EOB-MRI performed at the same time showed that the multiple liver masses still presented.
The CT scan performed 2 months later showed a decrease in the hepatic mass, and the CT scan performed 3 months later showed that the hepatic mass had almost completely disappeared.

Discussion: We managed a case involving necrotizing multiple hepatic masses probably caused by the administration of the anti-PD-L1 antibody following the course of radiochemotherapy given to treat non-small cell lung cancer.

In recent years, immune checkpoint inhibitors, including anti-PD-L1 antibodies, have been used for the treatment of various types of cancer, but current experience remains limited and the side effects are not fully understood.

The histopathological findings in this case supported a suspicion of hepatotoxicity caused by the radiochemotherapy rather than an autoimmune mechanism caused by immune checkpoint inhibitors, but nonetheless the emergence of necrotic multiple hepatic masses in the irradiated liver due to radiochemotherapy acting alone is extremely rare.

Therefore, it is most reasonable to assume that the administration of the anti-PD-L1 antibody, in conjunction with the radiochemotherapy, effected the development of the necrotic multiple hepatic masses for this case.

Conclusion: We managed a case involving necrotizing multiple hepatic masses that was probably impacted by the administration of the anti-PD-LI antibody following radiochemotherapy had been given for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer.

Background: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are now available for use in treatment of a variety of diseases, and reports of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) specific to side effects, have been on the increase.
Although autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) like pathological findings have been reported in liver related irAE, in recent years cholangitis has also been reported.
In this study we report our experience with a case of cholangitis involving nivolumab which had a variety of histopathological findings.
Case Report: 64-year-old male, who 1 year ago, underwent a pylorus-preserving gastrectomy for the treatment of gastric cancer.
The patient received nivolumab as 3rd line chemotherapy for prevention of postoperative complications of peritoneal and left supraclavicular lymph node recurrence.

entities.name: peritoneal and left supraclavicular lymph node recurrence

text: After 3 courses of nivolumab, the patient presented a psoriasis type drug eruption.
Concomitantly, the hepatobiliary enzymes AST 93 U/L, ALT 94 U/L, ALP 1341 U/L and γGTP 149 U/L were found to be elevated.
The hepatitis virus marker was negative, anti-nuclear antibody 80X, anti-mitochondrial antibody negative, IgG 1645.6 mg/dL, IgG4 20.5 mg/dL and IgM 45.1 mg/dL.
CT and MRCP gave no evidence of dilatation of the common bile duct or intrahepatic bile duct.

entities.name: common bile duct or intrahepatic bile duct

text: Since irAE was suspected, a liver biopsy was ordered.

Histopathological findings showed moderate inflammatory cell infiltration and endotheliitis in the portal region, with damage to the bile duct epithelium, along with lymphocytic infiltration of the bile duct.

entities.name: damage to the bile duct epithelium, along with lymphocytic infiltration

text: In the lobules, there were noncaseating epithelial cell granulomas containing Langhans-type multinucleated giant cells.

entities.name: noncaseating epithelial cell granulomas containing Langhans-type multinucleated giant cells

text: The lymphocytes in the portal vein area were CD8-positive and CD4-positive, and cholangitis involving nivolumab was the diagnosis.
After 3 weeks of treatment with PSL 0.5 mg/kg, AST 11 U/L, ALT 26 U/L, ALP 566 U/L, and γGTP 73 U/L values improved.
However, the patient suffered a relapse 2 weeks after reducing the PSL dosage to 0.4 mg/kg.
4 weeks later, AST 100 U/L, ALT 104 U/L, ALP 1215 U/L and γGTP 328 U/L values had worsened.
A second liver biopsy was ordered.
Histopathological findings of the second liver biopsy showed moderate inflammatory cell infiltration in the portal region and a small number of plasma cells.
Inter-face hepatitis, lymphoid infiltration of the bile duct epithelium, and lobular lymphocyte aggregation were also observed.
The infiltrating lymphocytes were CD8-positive and CD4-positive, identical to the first biopsy.
After increasing the dosage of PSL to 1 mg/kg, hepatobiliary enzyme levels decreased, and even after reducing the PSL dosage to 0.2 mg/kg, no relapse occurred.
Discussion: ICI related hepatotoxicity presented with a variety of histological features.
In this case, the first liver biopsy revealed granuloma formation and the visual was similar to that associated with primary bilious cholangitis.

entities.name: visual was similar to that associated with primary bilious cholangitis

text: The second liver biopsy revealed AIH like findings, i.e.
plasma cell infiltration and interface hepatitis, suggesting that there are various pathogenesis mechanisms for ICI related liver disorders.

entities.name: plasma cell infiltration and interface hepatitis

text: Case Report: A male in his 60s, was receiving nivolumab 150 mg every 2 weeks as second-line treatment for his laryngeal cancer at the Department of Otorhinolaryngology in our hospital.
Four months after starting treatment, blood work results at: T-bil 0.81 mg/dl, AST 91 U/l, ALT 144 U/l, ALP 1478 U/l and γGT 426 U/l.
Since liver damage with the dominance of biliary enzymes was also observed, the patient was referred to the Department of Gastroenterology.
The patient had no subjective symptoms and other than a fever of 37.6°C there were no special findings upon abdominal examination.
Blood biochemical tests showed that various viral markers, i.e. ANA and AMA2, were negative, and IgG and IgG4 were within normal limits.

entities.name: various viral markers, i.e. ANA and AMA2,

text: The CT scan showed enlarged gallbladder and thickened gallbladder wall along with diffuse dilatation and wall thickening of the common bile duct, and right and left hepatic ducts, but MRCP and ERC did not show any stenosis or neoplastic lesions in the bile ducts.

entities.name: enlarged gallbladder and thickened gallbladder wall
common bile duct, and right and left hepatic ducts

text: Hepatic tissue was free of inflammatory changes or necrosis of the hepatocytes, but there were various inflammatory cell infiltrates in the portal region and some chronic nonsuppurative destructive cholangitis.

entities.name: inflammatory changes or necrosis of the hepatocytes

text: We suspected immune checkpoint inhibitor related cholangitis and so discontinued the nivolumab, but the biochemical and imaging findings showed no improvement, so a course of PSL 30 mg was started.
Hepatobiliary enzymes levels slowly improved, but when the PSL dose was reduced to 15 mg, there was further exacerbation of the cholangitis and so UDCA 600 mg was started.
Thereafter, the cholangitis improved, and PSL was terminated and only UDCA was administered.
Nivolumab had not failed the patient, but after the medication was stopped the tumor progressed.
Systematic chemotherapy using cytotoxic anticancer drug proved ineffective, however while undergoing the cancer therapy the patient's cholangitis was not exacerbated.
Therefore, in support of the patient's strong request, it was agreed to restart the Nivolumab.
More than 8 months later, there were no signs that the liver function was further compromised, and furthermore, the tumor had started to shrink again.
Reports of cholangitis being a side effect (irAE) associated with immune checkpoint inhibitors are rare.
As of this writing, there is no consensus on how to treat.
It is not clear whether anti-PD-1 antibodies should be reintroduced or permanently discontinued after recovery from irAEs, including those involving cholangitis.
In this report, we describe a rare case of improvement for a patient with cholangitis caused by combination treatment with PSL and UDCA, and reintroduction of anti-PD-1 antibody under UDCA alone.

Opening Remarks: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are immunotherapy drugs that are able to suppress a tumor by inhibiting the immunosuppressive response and allow the immune system to attack the tumor.
After ICIs were approved for use in the treatment of malignant melanoma in 2014, their use has expanded to include the treatment of gastric cancer, and others.
However the frequency of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) has also been on the rise.
Hepatotoxicity irAEs have a variety of clinical manifestations with much still remaining unclear.
Here we report a case of hepatic impairment we suspect was caused by an immune checkpoint inhibitor.
Case Report: Female in her 70s.
Past Medical History: Hypertension, hyperlipidemia.
History of alcohol consumption: None.

Current Medical History: Nivolumab, an anti-PD1 antibody, was prescribed by the Department of Dermatology at our hospital to treat vulvar malignant melanoma and lung metastasis in June, 1 year before 20XX.

entities.name: vulvar malignant melanoma and lung metastasis

text: Subsequently, the lung metastases tended to shrink, and the primary vulvar tumor was resected in November, 1 year before 20XX.
Nivolumab was administered for up to 15 courses, but in January 20XX, metastatic lesions presented in the vulva, and the lung metastatic lesions tended to increase.
Ipilimumab, an anti-CTLA-4 antibody, was started in late February 20XX, and a second course was administered up until mid-March.
In early April 20XX, when the patient was admitted to the hospital's dermatology department, there were no subjective symptoms.

entities.name: when the patient was admitted to the hospital's dermatology department

text: However the blood test results were: T-Bil 0.7 mg/dL, AST 6781 U/L, ALT 5381 U/L, ALP 211 U/L, γ-GTP 481 U/L, PT 87.2%, white blood cell count 7,950/μL and CRP 3.97 mg/dL, indicating mild liver dysfunction with an inflammatory reaction, and the patient was referred to our department for a consult.

entities.name: liver dysfunction with an inflammatory reaction

text: Both the hepatitis virus and autoantibody tests were negative.
Abdominal echography revealed no morphological changes in the liver and no significant findings for the bile ducts.
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen revealed no malignant hepatic lesions, hepatic infarction, portal vein thrombus or bile duct malignancy.

entities.name: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen
malignant hepatic lesions, hepatic infarction, portal vein thrombus or bile duct malignancy

text: A liver biopsy was performed 3 days later and revealed increased collagen fibers and inflammatory cell infiltration, mainly lymphocytes, in the portal and central venous regions, but only minimal inflammatory cell infiltration in the bile duct epithelium and no fibrous thickening of the bile ducts.

entities.name: increased collagen fibers and inflammatory cell infiltration, mainly lymphocytes

text: The score, in accordance with the diagnostic criteria for drug-induced liver injury revised by the DDW-J 2004 Workshop, fornivolumab was 8 points and for ipilimumab 9 points.
Therefore, it was considered as a possible suspect for this apparent drug-induced hepatic impairment.
PSL 45 mg/day (1 mg/kg/day) was administered from the 4th day.
The level of hepatic dysfunction decreased, and the PSL was gradually tapered off.
The patient was discharged 49 days after her illness commenced.
Discussion: IrAEs as a proximate cause of liver damage, hepatitis with elevated hepatobiliary enzymes, hepatitis and sclerosing cholangitis have been reported.

entities.name: liver damage, hepatitis with elevated hepatobiliary enzymes, hepatitis and sclerosing cholangitis

text: It should be noted that the mechanism of ICIs induced hepatotoxicity is different from that of conventional allergic or metabolic drug induced hepatotoxicity inasmuch as the former may appear as an autoimmune response, in addition to cross-reactivity between neoantigen and autoantigen in cancer cells.
From the progression of the illness it was suspected that ICIs might be the cause of the liver damage and the findings of the liver biopsy formed the basis of our evaluation.

entities.name: ICIs might be the cause of the liver damage

text: Opening Remarks: In recent years, for the treatment of several different types of malignant cancer, immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) have proven promising, with their efficacy duly recognized.
Although ICIs can be effective in attacking a tumor by the inhibition of immunosuppressive signals, there have also been reports of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) affecting various organs.
In this report we describe a remarkable case of bile stasis liver failure that occurred after the use of an ICI.
Case Report: 83-year-old male being dosed with ICI (nivolumab and ipilimumab) for recurrent pleural metastasis of renal cell carcinoma.
The drugs had been administered 4 times, but the medication was halted due to the worsened condition.
Later, pazopanib was administered, but it was observed that jaundice and liver failure had set in.
Since the condition continued to worsen, pazopanib was halted and the patient was started on PSL 60 mg, but due to worsening jaundice, the patient was transferred to our department.
Although the patient was transferred to our department and treated with steroid pulse therapy, the jaundice did not improve.
The liver biopsy showed chronic non-pyogenic destructive cholangitis, marked bile stasis, and PBC-like findings.

entities.name: chronic non-pyogenic destructive cholangitis, marked bile stasis

text: The infiltrating lymphocytes were CD8 positive and thought to be due to an irAE.
Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) was administered, but the patient's general condition deteriorated after several days of being on the medication, and he died.

entities.name: after several days of being on the medication

text: Discussion: Although steroids are recommended for the treatment of irAE induced liver disease, in this case the condition proved refractory for both pulse therapy and steroids.
In recent years various levels of bile duct injury have been reported in connection with liver related irAEs.
Steroid resistance for cases involving liver damage, including bile duct injury, which are irAEs related have also been reported.

entities.name: liver damage, including bile duct injury, which are irAEs related

text: The use of MMF has been reported to be effective in steroid resistant patients, and was introduced in this case, but it was not possible to evaluate its efficacy.

Although the number of cases of liver damage due to irAEs is expected to increase in the future, it is necessary to build up a number of cases and to also consider early immunosuppressive therapy as part of the treatment strategy.
Case Report: A 74-year-old female.
The patient was receiving outpatient treatment at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology in our hospital for pulmonary and splenic metastasis of uterine leiomyosarcoma.

entities.name: pulmonary and splenic metastasis of uterine leiomyosarcoma

text: On December 19, 201X the patient was started on 800 mg of oral pazopanib.

For the blood sample taken on January 22, one year after 201X the results were: T-Bil  7.85 mg/dl, D-Bil 5.07 mg/dl, AST 559 IU/L, ALT 515 IU/L, LDH 747 IU/L and ALP 1490 IU/L, indicating a mixed type of markedly elevated liver enzymes, which resulted in our department being called in for a consult.
Autoantibodies and viral markers were negative.
DLST for pazopanib was negative.

As per the DDW-J 2004 Drug-Induced Liver Injury Workshop scoring, the total score: 5 points, days since onset: 2 points, existence of non-drug related causes (Y/N): 2 points and previous liver disorder reported: 1 point.
We suspected drug-induced hepatotoxicity due to pazopanib and decided to discontinue the medication and follow-up with the patient.

However, for the blood sample taken one week later the results were: T-Bil 22.37 mg/dl, D-Bil 15.02 mg/dl, AST 447 IU/L, ALT 348 IU/L LDH 499 IU/L and ALP 2360 IU/L, indicating that the patient's liver function had tended to worsen due to cholestasis.

entities.name: liver function had tended to worsen

text: A liver biopsy was performed on the same day in order to investigate the cause.

The liver histology showed cholestasis in the hepatocytes around the central vein, inflammatory cell infiltration with small lymphocytes in Glisson's sheath and focal hepatocellular necrosis in the lobules, indicating drug-induced hepatic impairment with impaired bile transport and hepatitis.

entities.name: drug-induced hepatic impairment with impaired bile transport and hepatitis

text: The possibility of tumor exacerbation was considered, but liver function abnormalities were the main findings, and so steroid pulse therapy (500 mg/day) was started the same day.
After 1 week, the hepatobiliary enzymes showed signs of improving, and the steroid dose was gradually tapered off.
2 months later the hepatobiliary enzymes had normalized.

Although there have been many reports in Japan of drug-induced hepatic impairment caused by pazopanib, there are few reports of a liver biopsy performed at Grade 4, as in this case, resulting in a definitive diagnosis.

Here we report a case of drug-induced hepatotoxicity due to the taking of pazopanib for a patient who responded to pulsed steroid therapy, and include our experience as drawn from other cases we have handled.
Objective: immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) have demonstrated an ability to fight tumors by suppressing the immune system.
On the other hand, ICIs are known to cause immune-related Adverse Effects (irAEs) in various organs, and some cases, deaths have been reported.
Hepatotoxicity is a frequent immune-related adverse effect.
According to the package insert, hepatotoxicity and hepatitis are observed in approximately 10% of all patients.
A liver biopsy can show an autoimmune hepatitis like appearance, but to date there have been few reports.
Here we report a case of acute hepatic impairment caused by pembrolizumab.
Case Report: A male in his 60s.
In November 201X the patient was given a diagnosis of Stage 4 lung cancer with bone metastasis.
PD-L1 expression was confirmed.
A course of pembrolizumab was started at 200 mg for every 3 weeks in December.
AST and ALT values were 44 IU/L and 63 IU/L, respectively.
Treatment was given in 4 courses.
Blood samples taken at the end of the fifth course had results of: AST 120 IU/L and ALT 176 IU/L.

entities.name: at the end of the fifth course

text: The administration of the medicine was stopped.
However, afterwards the patient was hospitalized due to a greater level of liver dysfunction combined with decreased appetite.
Height 163 cm, Weight 66 kg.
Abdominal findings were unremarkable.
On admission the lab results were: AST 1361 IU/L, ALT 1593 IU/L, T-Bil  1.1 mg/dL, IgG 1027 mg/dl.
PT 81%, M2BPGi 1.06, ANA 40x, HCV antibody negative, HBsAg negative.
Echocardiography revealed no fatty liver, atrophy or ascites.
Pathological findings: extensive hepatocyte shedding, hemorrhage, and infiltration of macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells around the central vein.

entities.name: hepatocyte shedding, hemorrhage, and infiltration of macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells

text: There was spotty necrosis in the lobules and mild lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the portal region.
After treatment (1000 mg of methylprednisolone) for 3 days, AST and ALT levels improved to 270 IU/L and 822 IU/L respectively.
Thereafter, prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day was started, which was gradually tapered off, and AST/ALT levels reached the baseline in approximately 2 months time.

Discussion: One of the characteristics of immune checkpoint inhibitors is their efficacy continues even after the medication is no longer administered, such that their efficacy against the tumor will continue.
On the other hand, it has also been remarked that irAEs also persist over time.

Drug-induced hepatic impairment of the hepatocellular damage type will usually see quick resolution of the liver disorder by discontinuing the causative drug, but there have been cases of exacerbation even after discontinuing immune checkpoint inhibitors.
In this case, after discontinuing the medication, the liver enzymes level increased rapidly.
It is essential to perform a liver biopsy at an early stage to confirm the diagnosis, and then to begin steroids as soon as possible.
Case Study: 53 year old female patient.
Chief Complaint: Fever.
Progress: Patient was seen at the dermatology department of our hospital 2 years before 20XX and presented a skin rash that the diagnosis identified as bullous pemphigoid.
Prednisolone (PSL) 1 mg/kg/day was introduced and the patient was managed with concomitant immunomodulators with a gradual decrease in the PSL level.
PSL was voluntarily discontinued in August, 20XX when the PSL dosage had been reduced to 6 mg/day, but there was no worsening of the skin rash.
On September 9, she felt a malaise, and on September 10  she developed a fever of 38°C.
She was seen at our clinic.

The patient was admitted to our department as an emergency case because she presented elevated bilirubin levels with direct type predominance, a mildly decreased PT of 74%, and CT findings suggestive of acute hepatitis.
The patient resumed PSL at the same dosage as when she voluntarily stopped taking the medication and was also started on CMZ for a suspected infection.
Liver function showed improvement, but the eosinophils slowly increased, and erythema broke out all over her body.
Her skin rash was different from the original pemphigus, and was suspected to be a skin eruption caused by the CMZ.
The antibacterial medication was stopped as of September 17.
Although the underlying cause of the disorder was not clear, her fever abated gradually.
Despite the persistence of eosinophilia it was decided to discharge the patient on September 24.
However, 2 days later the fever once again presented itself, and as the patient showed no improvement, she was readmitted to the hospital on October 1.
After readmission, the patient showed sudden prolongation of coagulation, hematopenia and the progression of jaundice, and was diagnosed as having non-comatose acute liver failure.

entities.name: prolongation of coagulation, hematopenia and the progression of jaundice

text: After confirming that there were no contraindications for PSL such as a bacterial infection or malignancy, PSL pulse therapy was started on October 6 to treat the acute liver failure.
After the start of PSL, the patient's fever dropped quickly and liver function improved.
The eosinophil level had not dropped and the neutrophils level was at (100/ul).
It was also clear that the reduced level of neutrophils was persisting.
However, the bone marrow biopsy revealed no abnormalities in the hematopoiesis.
After tapering off the PSL no liver injury or recurrence of fever was observed and blood cell reduction improved over the course of approximately one month.

entities.name: liver injury or recurrence of fever

text: The patient was discharged on October 27.
Since then, the patient has been tapered off PSL without recurrence of a skin rash or liver damage.

entities.name: recurrence of a skin rash or liver damage

text: Discussion: We managed a case of acute liver failure with remarkable eosinophilia.

Various blood tests, imaging studies and histological examinations were performed, but the results were negative for infection, including parasites, blood flow disorders, autoimmune diseases, neoplastic lesions and hematological diseases.

entities.name: Various blood tests, imaging studies and histological examinations
infection, including parasites, blood flow disorders, autoimmune diseases, neoplastic lesions and hematological diseases

text: Histologically, perivascular infiltrates, mainly eosinophils, were observed in the liver and skin, but a diagnosis of vasculitis was not reached, and both were judged to be secondary changes.
Acute hepatic failure with eosinophilia is an extremely rare occurrence, and we report it here with a discussion of the pathological findings of the liver, skin, and bone marrow samples.
Case Study: 26 year old, male.
Chief Complaint: Jaundice, lower limb edema and dysbasia.

entities.name: Jaundice, lower limb edema and dysbasia

text: Current Medical History: The patient had no familial disposition to hepatitis and no past surgical history, or history of blood transfusion or dietary intake of animal meats, which are the usual causative factors for this disease.
Since the age of 20, he had been drinking beer, sake, whiskey, other, equivalent to 200-300 g alcohol per day.
He was admitted to the hospital for suspected cholecystitis in March, 20XX.
At that time, patient was informed he had alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver.
The patient had been aware of the edema in his lower legs and yellowish staining of urine since August, 20XX.

entities.name: edema in his lower legs and yellowish staining of urine

text: From that time forward, it gradually became difficult to climb stairs and then hard to maintain a standing position, and he was rushed to our hospital for emergency treatment in October, 20XX.

entities.name: hard to maintain a standing position

text: On admission, as for physical findings, manifest jaundice, pruritus, and leg edema appeared , but no hepatic encephalopathy was observed.

entities.name: manifest jaundice, pruritus, and leg edema

text: Contrast CT scan showed chronic liver injury, splenomegaly, worsening of the subcutaneous edema, bilateral pleural effusions, pulmonary edema and right upper lobe infiltration.

entities.name: chronic liver injury, splenomegaly, worsening of the subcutaneous edema
bilateral pleural effusions, pulmonary edema and right upper lobe infiltration

text: Blood test results: AST 58IU/l, ALT l8IU/l, ALP 175IU/l, γ-GTP 208IU/l, LDH 449U/1, ChE 102U/1, T-bill 12.7mg/dl, D-bill 5.4mg/dl, PT 30%, Cu 90μg/dl, M2BPGi 12.16COI.

Various hepatitis viral markers were negative, CMV and EBV related antigen-antibody reactions were also of negative pattern, IgG 1569 mg/dl, antinuclear antibody less than 40-fold, and anti-M2 antibody was also negative.

entities.name: CMV and EBV related antigen-antibody reactions

text: WBC 4900/μl, RBC 410×104/μl, Hb 2.1 g/dl, Ht 6.2%, MCV 151.2 fl, MCHC 51.2 Pg, Plt  10.7x104/ul.
A peripheral blood smear showed crushed erythrocytes and spur cells reflecting hemolysis.

entities.name: crushed erythrocytes and spur cells reflecting hemolysis

text: Percutaneous liver biopsy revealed ballooning of hepatocytes and Mallory body, hepatocyte region fibrosis, and inflammatory cell infiltration, supporting a diagnosis of alcoholic cirrhosis and associated spur cell anemia.

entities.name: ballooning of hepatocytes and Mallory body
alcoholic cirrhosis and associated spur cell anemia

text: The patient was given nutritional therapy for liver cirrhosis and a blood transfusion for anemia, but the permeability of the pulmonary area gradually decreased and the patient showed poor oxygenation.
Blood transfusions, plasma filtration with dialysis and continuous intravenous diuretics were administered for ventilatory management.

entities.name: Blood transfusions, plasma filtration with dialysis

text: After multidisciplinary treatment, the patient was able to be weaned from the ventilator and is now, after being discharged from the hospital, being seen on an outpatient basis.
Discussion: Spur cell anemia is a rare complication of liver cirrhosis first described by Smith et al in 1964.

In the peripheral blood smear abnormal red blood cells, covered with spike-like projections, in addition to spur cells, were seen and confirmed this as a very serious condition marked by hemolytic change.
Spur cell anemia is reported to be a poor prognostic factor for cirrhosis, and a liver transplant is the preferred course of treatment.
However, in this case, by applying multidiscilplinary therapy, it was possible to avoid the necessity of a liver transplant and it has been possible to continue treatment on an outpatient basis.
There have been few reports of juvenile alcoholic cirrhosis complicated by spur cell anemia having a good outcome.

entities.name: juvenile alcoholic cirrhosis complicated by spur cell anemia

text: Background: Hepatic encephalopathy caused by an intrahepatic portal hepatic vein shunt is often associated with background diseases including liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension.

entities.name: Hepatic encephalopathy caused by an intrahepatic portal hepatic vein shunt

text: In this presentation we report a case of an acute onset of hepatic encephalopathy without evidence of underlying liver disease, the cause of which was diagnosed as an intrahepatic portal hepatic vein shunt and was treated with percutaneous transhepatic obliteration (PTO).
Case Report: Patient is a 68 year old male.
During treatment for a myocardial infarction, the patient presented symptoms of somnolence and hyperammonemia (193 μg/dL - blood test result).
The T1-weighted head MRI showed high signal intensity in the bilateral globus pallidus, and the patient was diagnosed having impaired consciousness caused by hepatic encephalopathy.

entities.name: impaired consciousness caused by hepatic encephalopathy

text: Suspicion of acquired metabolic imbalance, other, resulted in his being admitted upon referral to our hospital (first time).
No history of drinking.
HBs antigen found negative, HCV antibody found negative.
At the time of his transfer from the previous hospital, ammonia level was 176 μg/dL, Fisher ratio 1.4 (normal: 2.43 - 4.40), and blood citrulline at 27.8 nmol/mL (normal: 17.1 - 42.6 nmol/mL).

entities.name: At the time of his transfer from the previous hospital,

text: Abdominal echocardiography showed no abnormalities in the morphology of the liver, but the left portal vein branch was dilated, and a portal hepatic vein shunt was suspected after running a Doppler test.
Contrast-enhanced CT scan showed only an intrahepatic shunt, with no extrahepatic shunt detected.
Lactitol, prescribed by the previous physician, was continued at a higher dosage, but with little improvement and it was decided to perform a PTO.
Portal angiography showed numerous non-expandable shunts in both lobes in addition to the shunt in the left branch of the portal vein found on the CT scan.

entities.name: left branch of the portal vein

text: A metal coil was used to obliterate an aneurysmal portal hepatic venous shunt in the left branch of the portal vein.

entities.name: left branch of the portal vein

text: After treatment, the ammonia level immediately normalized (42 μg/dL) and remained stable.
After discontinuation of lactitol, no increase in the ammonia level was observed.
Discussion: This case of hepatic encephalopathy occurred suddenly without evidence of any underlying liver disease.
However, use of an abdominal echo and contrast CT scan made possible an immediate diagnosis and appropriate course of treatment.

entities.name: abdominal echo and contrast CT scan

text: Hepatic encephalopathy has been reported to be caused by portal venous shunts associated with cirrhosis, portal hypertension, acquired metabolic imbalance of the urea cycle, as well as other causes.

entities.name: portal venous shunts associated with cirrhosis, portal hypertension

text: As in this case, the disease may be due to portal venous shunts without liver disease, although in such a case, an intrahepatic portal vein shunt being the proximate cause is rare.

entities.name: portal venous shunts without liver disease

text: If there is a history of trauma or liver biopsy the cause is presumed to be acquired.
The patient had no previous medical history except for an acute myocardial infarction, which was considered congenital.

There have been reports of hepatic encephalopathy being diagnosed asymptomatically or only first detected in geriatric patients, and this should be kept in mind as a differential factor for hepatic encephalopathy in patients with non-cirrhotic liver.
Conclusion: Successful percutaneous transhepatic obliteration involving hepatic encephalopathy caused by an intrahepatic portal vein-hepatic vein shunt.

entities.name: hepatic encephalopathy caused by an intrahepatic portal vein-hepatic vein shunt

text: Case Study: 82 year old female.

Chief Complaint: Impaired consciousness Past Medical History: 11 years before 20XX- chronic hepatitis C IFN treatment, one year before 20XX- cirrhosis C 2 oral drugs (DCV + ASV) SVR, December 11, one year before 20XX- aortic valve stenosis, TAVI procedure.
Current Medical History & Clinical Progress: The patient was treated with DCV + ASV for cirrhosis of the liver, type C in one year before 20XX and was judged to have SVR.

entities.name: cirrhosis of the liver, type C

text: Thereafter, a treatment strategy of regularly scheduled follow-up visits was adopted.
On December 11, one year before 20XX a TAVI procedure was performed for aortic valve stenosis.
The procedure went smoothly, but post-operative the patient began to experience impaired consciousness and hyperammonemia.
The patient was transferred to another hospital on January 8,  20XX for post-operative rehabilitation, but at this hospital she had another episode of impaired consciousness and hyperammonemia.
It was felt that the patient was responding well to conservative treatment.
However, during the course of treatment the patient presented both edema and dyspnea.
Based on a diagnosis of an acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure the patient was transferred to the Department of Cardiology at our hospital.

entities.name: acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure

text: A diuretic was administered and the heart failure showed improvement, however a recurrence of the hyperammonemia was observed.

From then on, and in holding true to the objective of pursuing a conservative course of treatment, it was decided to transfer the patient to another department after we completed a thorough examination.
The hepatic reserve was comparatively good after SVR, with a Child Pugh grade A (6 points).
On the stomach, spleen left renal vein was found a portosystemic shunt; this shunt, in combination with the cirrhosis, had a significant effect.
At this juncture, while continuing to treat for heart failure, the risk of repeated hepatic encephalopathy was judged high, and we decided to perform a percutaneous transhepatic obliteration.
Percutaneous transhepatic obliteration was performed on March 1.
The procedure was executed without any difficulty, and the patient recovered without any major post-operative complications.
The postoperative blood ammonia level quickly normalized, and there was no concurrent complication due to encephalopathy.

Discussion: Although hepatic encephalopathy is a phenotype of uncompensated liver cirrhosis, aggressive treatment is indicated because it decreases a patients' QOL and can greatly degrade their dignity.
Medical treatment includes restriction of protein intake and oral or intravenous administration of lactulose or branched-chain amino acid preparations.

entities.name: lactulose or branched-chain amino acid preparations

text: Recently, the therapeutic usefulness of rifaximin and L-Carnitine preparations, which are non-absorbable antibiotics, has been reported.
If it is determined thatcirrhosis is the clear cause of a portosystemic shunt, treatment may prove difficult.

In such cases, retrograde transvenous embolization under balloon occlusion, portal vein diversion or percutaneous transhepatic obliteration are the treatments of choice, with improvement usually being the outcome.

entities.name: retrograde transvenous embolization under balloon occlusion, portal vein diversion or percutaneous transhepatic obliteration

text: However, in some cases, ascites and varicose vein exacerbation have been reported.
In this case, strict fluid management was necessary due to heart failure, and shunt obliteration was indicated because the patient had easily developed encephalopathy due to dehydration.
After the treatment the prognosis has remained positive, and even with further treatment later on, no recurrence of encephalopathy has been observed.
With the advent of rifaximin and L-Cartine, it is possible to control many hepatic comas.
However, in some patients, especially those with thick walled portal veins and large circulatory short circuits, hepatic coma is difficult to control even with these medications.

entities.name: portal veins and large circulatory short circuits

text: Here we report a case of C-type cirrhosis in which hepatic coma was successfully controlled by obliteration of the splenic-renal shunt using the AmplatzerTM Vascular Plug.
Case Report: 80 year old female patient.
Chief Complaint: Impaired consciousness.
Past Medical History: Esophageal varices.
Current Medical History: Patient is undergoing treatment for hepatic cirrhosis type C.
However, for approximately the past 5 years, hepatic coma has been observed.
Initially, the condition was well under control with the use of lactulose and BCAAs alone, but gradually became less controllable.
Rifaximin and levocarnitine were added, and the patient frequently fell into hepatic coma despite receiving intravenous BCAAs 3X/week.
While being treated in the ER, the patient presented impaired consciousness.
Progress: The patient was in a hepatic coma, Grade 3 at the time of consultation.
Blood chemistry test results: Alb 3.0 g/dL, T.Bil 1.1 mg/dL, NH3 138 μg/dL, PLT 11.8x10^4/μL, PT 63.6%, PT-INR 1.30.
Contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a thick splenic-renal shunt.
After administering an intravenous BCAA infusion consciousness level improved to hepatic coma, grade 1 level.
After carefully detailing the situation to the patient's family and securing informed consent, a splenorenal shunt occlusion was performed.
The splenic renal shunt was approached from the right femoral vein and obliterated with an AmplatzerTM Vascular Plug.

entities.name: obliterated with an AmplatzerTM Vascular Plug

text: No particular intraoperative complications were observed.
The following day, NH3 improved to a level of 47 μg/dL, and hepatic coma did not present post treatment.

Discussion: BRTO, when combined with ethanolamine oleate (EO), is often successful in the treatment of hepatic coma involving a thick splenic-renal shunt when oral medications such as rifaximin and lactulose have proven unsuccessful.
However, haptoglobin is required to prevent renal damage caused by intravascular hemolysis due to the large amount of EO administered.

entities.name: renal damage caused by intravascular hemolysis

text: There is also a risk of a pulmonary embolism if the balloon is not fully occluded, and a further risk of hepatic infarction if EO flows into the portal vein.
Obliteration using a vascular plug was considered to be a safe procedure free from these risks.
Conclusion: We have reported a case of hepatic coma controlled by obliteration of a splenic-renal shunt using a vascular plug.

Background: In Japan the balloon-occluded retrogade transvenous obliteration (BRTO) procedure is often performed for the treatment of gastric varices associated with cirrhosis, and is recommended in the Guidelines for the Treatment of Cirrhosis 2015.

On the other hand, partial splenic artery embolization, hereinafter known as PSE is a treatment method that can reduce splenic volume, correct splenic hyperplasia, and improve portal pressure and hepatic function by partially embolizing the splenic artery.

entities.name: partial splenic artery embolization, hereinafter known as PSE

text: Here we report a case involving alcoholic cirrhosis complicated by gastric varices with giant splenomegaly and thrombocytopenia involvement for which PSE was performed as part of prior therapy and BRTO was performed as a wait-and-see treatment.

entities.name: alcoholic cirrhosis complicated by gastric varices

text: We are able to report that the result was an improvement both for gastric varices and hepatic function.
Case Report: Male patient in his 70s.
The patient was receiving treatment for alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver from his local physician at the time he was referred to our department in 20XX for the treatment of esophageal varices.
Upper endoscopy revealed esophageal varices (Lm, F3, Cb, RC0) and gastric varices (Lg-cf, F1, RC0).
Endoscopic sclerotherapy for varicose veins was given, and the esophageal varicose veins disappeared, so the patient's follow up was handled on an outpatient basis.
Periodic upper endoscopy and abdominal imaging examinations were given at the outpatient clinic.

entities.name: upper endoscopy and abdominal imaging examinations

text: The esophageal varices did not worsen, but the number of gastric varices gradually increased (Fl→F2).
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen showed giant splenomegaly, a splenic renal shunt, and gastric varices protruding into the gastric lumen.

entities.name: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen
giant splenomegaly, a splenic renal shunt

text: Furthermore, hypersplenism coupled with a low platelet count (50,000-70,000/μl) and hyperammonemia (around 100 mg/dl were also observed.

entities.name: hypersplenism coupled with a low platelet count

text: Therefore, we decided to improve splenic function by first performing a PSE and then treating the gastric varices with the BRTO procedure.
3 years after 20XX, an embolism using the PSE procedure was performed on approximately 80% of the entire spleen, centering on the inferior polar branch of the splenic artery.

entities.name: inferior polar branch of the splenic artery

text: The platelet count, prior to treatment, was at 73,000/μl; approximately one month post treatment the platelet count had increased to 158,000/μl, clear evidence of reversal of the hypersplenism.
Subsequently, BRTO was performed on the gastrorenal shunt flowing into the left adrenal vein.
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) revealed a lack of blood flow to the gastric varices.

2 months later upper endoscopy revealed the gastric varices had shrunk (Lg-cf, Fl, RC0) and this fact, taken together with the new platelet count of 150,000/μl and anammonia level of 32 mg/dl, allowed us to determine for an improvement in hepatic function.

Discussion and Conclusion: The results of this case suggest that BRTO can be performed more safely to gastric varices associated with cirrhosis with marked hypersplenism by preceding with a PSE, which may ultimately improve hepatic function.

entities.name: gastric varices associated with cirrhosis with marked hypersplenism

text: Background: The balloon occlusion retrograde transvenous obliteration (BRTO), developed in Japan, is a minimally invasive and effective IVR treatment of hepatic encephalopathy and gastric varices.
Furthermore, it has been reported that BRTO can improve liver reserve and prolong life expectancy.
Here, we report a case of dramatic improvement in liver function after BRTO in a patient with decompensated cirrhosis who had a large splenic renal shunt.

Current Medical History: A female patient in her late 60s who had been under observation at another hospital for decompensated cirrhosis of the liver type C (after sustaining a SVR), and had a history of multiple hospitalizations for hepatic encephalopathy.

entities.name: decompensated cirrhosis of the liver type C

text: The patient was referred to the Department of Surgery at a university hospital for the objective of receiving a liver transplant, but this was not possible, and she was referred to our department for a second opinion.
Biochemical Laboratory Blood Test Results: TB: 2.1 mg/dL, Alb: 2.7 g/dL, PT: 36.6% (INR: 1.80), Ammonia: 199 μg/dL, Cre: 0.59 mg/dL, Na: 140 mmol/L.
Imaging Findings: the dynamic CT scan showed severe hepatic atrophy (434.7 cm³) and a remarkedly developed splenic-renal shunt, but no ascites or hepatocellular carcinoma were found.
Doppler ultrasonography showed the portal venous blood flow was hepatotropic, splenic venous blood flow was distal hepatic, and liver hardness was 21.5 kPa as measured by a FibroScan.
Clinical Progress: We performed the BRTO procedure for this patient with scores of: Child-Pugh score: 11 and MELD-Na score: 16.

After the balloon occlusion test indicated that the postoperative increase in portal pressure was within the acceptable range, a total of 7 ml of 5% EOI was injected into the shunt, making for a successful thrombus.
The patient experienced neither complication or incident both during the surgery and postoperatively.

entities.name: both during the surgery and postoperatively

text: 7 months post surgery, test results were as follows: Child-Pugh score: 5, MELD-Na score: 8, all indicative of improvement.
Additional test results: TB: 0.9 mg/dL, Alb: 3.7 g/dL, PT: 79.3% (INR: 1.13), Ammonia: 29 ug/dL, Cre: 0.66 mg/dL, Na: 140 mmol/L.
The splenorenal shunt disappeared, and liver volume doubled to a level of (875.6 g/cm³).
There was no thoracic ascites and neither were the esophagogastric varices aggravated.

Discussion & Conclusion: Our department has reported that preoperative liver hardness is a prognostic factor after BRTO (J Gastroenterol Hepatol. 2019), and based on the evidence, determined the treatment strategy.
BRTO may be an alternative to a liver transplant for the treatment of decompensated cirrhosis.
Case Report: 70 year old, female.
A case of decompensated stage C cirrhosis (Child-Pugh score: 8B) with a 2 cm hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) at S3.

Not being appropriate for excision, we considered percutaneous localized therapy, but given that an extrahepatic shunt had developed from the umbilical vein and occupied the anterior surface of the left lateral lobes, it was not considered safe for needle puncture.

entities.name: anterior surface of the left lateral lobes

text: The patient was referred to a certain hospital for the objective of shunt occlusion, judging that if the shunt occlusion was successful, not only could localized therapy be safely managed, but also liver function could be restored and antiviral therapy could be administered.
At a joint conference of the Department of Surgery, Internal Medicine, and Radiology, it was decided to perform a percutaneous transsplenic umbilical vein occlusion and splenic artery embolization.
However, during the surgery intra-abdominal bleeding due to a splenic vein injury developed, and an emergency splenectomy and umbilical vein ligation were performed.

entities.name: intra-abdominal bleeding due to a splenic vein injury
emergency splenectomy and umbilical vein ligation

text: Post surgery, the shunt at the anterior surface of the extrahepatic area disappeared and liver function improved to a Child A level.

entities.name: anterior surface of the extrahepatic area

text: Percutaneous microwave ablation was performed.
The patient was then treated with sofosbuvir and regipasvir and achieved SVR.
As of now, 18 months have already elapsed since the operation without recurrence of HCC, and liver function remains good.

entities.name: 18 months have already elapsed since the operation

text: Discussion: In cirrhotic patients the development of portal-major circulatory shunts is a cause of shunted hepatic encephalopathy and decreased liver function.

entities.name: shunted hepatic encephalopathy and decreased liver function

text: Shunt occlusion is a highly effective treatment that not only reduces serum ammonia levels but also improves liver function.

Although less invasive transcatheter therapy such as BRTO should be considered as the first choice rather than laparotomy for shunt ligation, in this case, a transcatheter approach to the treating of the shunt proved difficult, and because of bleeding complications associated with the procedure, extrahepatic shunt ligation and splenectomy by laparotomy was undertaken as an alternate treatment strategy.
In terms of a result, after the operation, percutaneous localized therapy could be safely administered, liver function improved, and antiviral therapy could also be administered.
Therefore, if a transcatheter approach to the treatment of the shunt is difficult, as was in this case, laparotomy should be considered.
Case Study: Male patient in his 60s.
5 years before 20XX, the patient underwent surgical treatment for a pelvic fracture and ureteral injury due to traffic accident related trauma.

entities.name: a pelvic fracture and ureteral injury due to traffic accident related trauma

text: Every year he took a physical examination which included various blood tests, with no abnormal results being found.

entities.name: physical examination which included various blood tests

text: However, in December, 20XX, it was noted that his γ-GTP level was slightly elevated.
The patient was referred to our department after the imaging requested by his treating physician who had suggested there was an obstruction of the middle hepatic vein.
In May, 20XX, the patient was admitted to our hospital for the objective of further examination.
At the time of admission, although the physical examination yielded nothing remarkable, the blood test indicated a considerably elevated γ-GTP level (79 IU/L).
No other abnormalities were found for the blood count, coagulation test, or biochemical findings.

A dynamic computed tomography of the abdomen revealed a large right diaphragmatic hernia with protrusion of the right lobe of the liver, gallbladder, and hepatic flexure of the colon into the thoracic cavity.

entities.name: dynamic computed tomography of the abdomen
right lobe of the liver, gallbladder, and hepatic flexure of the colon

text: In particular, the hernia portal considerably excluded the inside of the hepatic hilum of the right lobe of the liver.

entities.name: inside of the hepatic hilum of the right lobe of the liver

text: The right hepatic vein was stenotic, the middle hepatic vein was obstructed and the reflux area of the middle hepatic vein was highly atrophic.

entities.name: reflux area of the middle hepatic vein

text: The subhepatic vena cava had no obvious point of origin for obstruction.
The MRCP examination revealed that the bile ducts were obscured at the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic ducts, and the intrahepatic bile ducts were slightly dilated in both lobes.

entities.name: at the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic ducts

text: Transarterial portal venography (CT) revealed heterogeneous staining of the right lobe of the liver, suggesting congestive hepatopathy.
The middle hepatic vein could not be identified.
Late phase of hepatic arteriographic CT scan showed the development of a venous short circuit.

entities.name: development of a venous short circuit

text: The hepatic venous wedge pressure, when measured, was 10 mmHg, which is within the normal range.
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed no varices in the esophagus or stomach.
Chest X-rays and abdominal CT scans taken after the traffic accident 5 years before 20XX were once again reviewed.

entities.name: Chest X-rays and abdominal CT scans

text: We found a partial hepatic prolapse from the right diaphragmatic hernia into the thoracic cavity, which was not seen in the chest X-ray of 9 years before 20XX.
The subsequent course the disease might take was unknown, but the hernia portal gradually opened and the volume of the enlarged liver increased.

The right and middle hepatic veins were mechanically drained, resulting in hemodynamics similar to the Budd-Chiari syndrome (type IV), and thus the patient was diagnosed as having Budd-Chiari syndrome (type IV).

entities.name: similar to the Budd-Chiari syndrome (type IV)

text: Since there is concern that the condition may worsen in the future, we are now considering surgical repair of the diaphragm.
We managed a case with hemodynamics similar to the Budd-Chiari syndrome hemodynamics 5 years after the diaphragmatic hernia caused by a traffic accident.

Objective: For patients with cirrhosis who present hematemesis and melena, we often find cases for which no obvious cause for the bleeding can be identified, even after performing an upper and lower endoscopy.

Here we report a case of cirrhosis in which a patient died of hemorrhagic shock at our hospital, and the pathological autopsy revealed the cause of death as portal hypertensive enteropathy induced by portal vein thrombosis.

entities.name: portal hypertensive enteropathy induced by portal vein thrombosis

text: Case Study: Patient was an 81 year old male with a history of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, who had been a patient at our hospital since 5 years before 20XX.

He was found collapsed at home in August 20XX and was rushed to our hospital with a complaint of decreased consciousness and a bloody bowel discharge Clinical Progress: His level of consciousness was measured at E4V5M6.

entities.name: decreased consciousness and a bloody bowel discharge

text: The patient presented with a low level of hematemesis, but with a considerable quantity of dark red stool.
We suspected upper gastrointestinal bleeding and performed repeated endoscopic examinations, but no obvious source of bleeding could be identified.
The same day, taking into consideration the rupture of the esophageal varices and possible hemostatis, the patient was given EIS.
On the following day, the patient presented without hematemesis, but on the third day, a considerable quantity of tar feces was discharged once more by the patient, followed by respiratory arrest.

entities.name: considerable quantity of tar feces was discharged

text: Although resuscitation was attempted, the patient expired without recovering.

Discussion: The pathological autopsy found the mucosa of the lower small to large intestine to be intermittently dark purple, and a considerable quantity of dark red bloody stool was found inside, evidence of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

entities.name: mucosa of the lower small to large intestine

text: Furthermore, mild vasodilation and dilatation of the lower gastrointestinal mucosa was discovered, suggesting portal hypertensive enteropathy was the cause of the lesion.

The portal vein thrombus, found in the earlier CT scan, extended into the superior mesenteric vein, suggesting that the vein's internal pressure increased due to portal hypertensive enteropathy, which may have further increased internal pressure, resulting in lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to a diffuse hemorrhage.

entities.name: lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to a diffuse hemorrhage

text: Conclusion: Portal hypertensive enteropathy has no characteristic endoscopic or pathological findings and there are currently no uniform diagnostic criteria or severity classification available.

It is also difficult to diagnose thrombosis because of nonspecific symptoms, and it has been reported that in 75% of the cases that 48 hours elapsed from the time the symptoms first appeared to a diagnosis being made.

For patients with portal hypertension coupled withthrombosis who present blood in the stool, it is important to differentiate between a massive bloody discharge due to diffuse bleeding from the lower gastrointestinal tract and thrombosis, and to consider the priority and necessity of additional tests and treatment as soon as thrombosis develops in patients with portal hypertensive disease.
Case Report: 87 year old, male.
Chief Complaint: General malaise, appetite loss Current Medical History: Patient visited his local physician with a complaint of general malaise and loss of appetite around January 20XX.

entities.name: general malaise and loss of appetite

text: Blood tests taken at the time indicated there was a slight increase in hepatobiliary enzymes.

However, as of July 20XX, a rapid increase in biliary enzymes was discovered, with the patient being referred to our department with the objective of having the patient undergo a thorough examination and discover the underlying cause of his condition.

Lab Results: AST 66 U/L, ALT 50 U/L, ALP 1025 U/L, γ-GTP 335 U/L, T-Bil 1.4 mg/dl, Plt 20.6x104/ul, PT 103%, HBs antigen (-), HCV antibody (-), anti-nuclear antibody ×160, anti-mitochondrial antibody ×80, anti-mitochondrial M2 index 88.5, IgG 1923 mg/dl IgM 523 mg/dl.
Clinical Course: Contrast-enhanced CT and abdominal ultrasonography indicated that the surface of the liver was uneven and irregular with blunted margins confirmingcirrhosis.
There was no obvious evidence of organic disease in the liver or bile ducts.
We suspected primary biliary cholangitis based on the blood test and imaging results.
A liver biopsy was taken, the pathological findings of which showed a moderate to severe infiltration of inflammatory cells, mainly lymphocytes, in the portal vein and sinusoids.
In part of the portal vein region, lymphocytic and histiocytic infiltrates were found in the bile duct epithelium as well as ductular proliferation in some areas.
Azan staining revealed bridging fibrosis in some areas.
Based on the findings of the blood tests and histopathological images the patient was diagnosed as having chronic non-pyogenic destructive cholangitis and symptomatic primary cholangitis.
Ursodeoxycholic acid (600 mg/day) was started once the diagnosis was made.
The hepatobiliary enzymes rapidly improved after the start of oral medication.

entities.name: after the start of oral medication

text: Since then the patient has been under observation at our outpatient clinic without any relapse.

Discussion: The distribution of primary biliary cholangitis by subject's age and estimated age of onset, when segregated by sex, is overwhelmingly higher in women, with most cases occurring between the ages of 45 and 60.
The incidence rate for those in the population who are over the age of 65 is approximately 12%, and as in this case, less than 2% for those over the age of 75, which makes it rare.
On the whole, the cumulative incidence of carcinogenesis is relatively low (2.5% at 10 years after diagnosis) for primary cholangitis.
However, it is significantly higher in males at 6.5% versus in females at 2.0% (6.5% in males and 2.0% in females).
Furthermore, for men over the age of 70, with a history of blood transfusion, it has been reported that the risk of cancer is exacerbated, so that screening is necessary.
In recent years, the average age for the onset of cholangitis has been rising, including those of the population who are of advanced years.

It is important to realize there is a possibility of primary biliary cholangitis when elevated hepatobiliary enzymes are detected, even for patients of highly advanced years, and to recognize the need to perform a thorough examination.
Conclusion: Here we report a rare, single case involving a geriatric male patient who was diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis.
Case Report: 15 year old male.
Chief Complaint: No symptoms, (examined for liver disorder).
Past Medical History: Nothing remarkable to report.
Family Medical History: No history of liver disorder or neuropsychiatric disease.
Clinical Progress: Although the patient presented no symptoms, he requested a blood test including blood typing and visited his local doctor.
Lab Results: AST 42 U/L, ALT 73 U/L, γ-GTP 36 U/L.
Diagnosis: Liver disorder.
Following the initial diagnosis, the patient was examined by his local doctor every 3 to 4 months.
However, after one year, he was referred to our department as the liver disorder persisted.
Patient was slightly obese with a BMI of 27.7 and presented neither neuropsychiatric symptoms or Kayser-Fleischer corneal rings.
Abdominal US revealed a fatty liver, and the blood tests suggested liver damage.
Lab Results: AST 51 U/L, ALT 109 U/L, γ-GTP 34, CHE  447 U/L, Hepatitis virus markers, ANA and AMA-M2Ab were negative.

entities.name: Hepatitis virus markers, ANA and AMA-M2Ab were negative

text: However, serum ceruloplasmin  tested at 13 mg/dl and serum copper tested at  55 μg/dl; both below the normal range.
Urinary copper tested at 72.8 μg/day, which was higher than the reference value.
With a possibility of Wilson's Disease additional tests were ordered.
A Penicillamine Challenge Test revealed an increase of 1474.2 μg/day of urinary copper, and a percutaneous liver biopsy was ordered.

Liver histology showed a diffuse fatty liver, and the copper level in the liver tissue was at 70.5 μg/g dry weight, which was higher than the reference value (<50 μg/g dry weight), but not high enough to confirm a diagnosis of Wilson's Disease.

entities.name: copper level in the liver tissue

text: However, copper is not uniformly present in liver tissues, and the copper level varies depending on the sampling site.
We fully explained the situation to the patient and his family, and consent was given to perform an ATP-7B gene test, however no mutation was found.
Based on the test results, in our consideration we believe it is unlikely that this is a case of Wilson's disease.

However, since genetic mutations have not been identified in more than 10% of cases involving Wilson's disease, we are following the patient's progress through regular follow-up visits as there is the possibility of heterozygosity.

Discussion: In the early stages of the disease and in the chronic hepatitis stage, Wilson's disease is known to present as fatty liver or fatty hepatitis, and in our department, the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is often made based on a diagnosis of fatty liver.

entities.name: early stages of the disease and in the chronic hepatitis stage

text: The patient also had fatty liver, decreased serum ceruloplasmin and serum copper levels and an increased level of urinary copper, so a Penicillamine Challenge Test, copper level measurement in the liver tissue were carried out.

entities.name: Penicillamine Challenge Test, copper level measurement in the liver tissue

text: However, none of the tests results were beyond the normal range and did not support a diagnosis of Wilson's disease, nor were any genetic mutations found.

At this juncture, although we think it very unlikely in this case that it is Wilson's disease, it is to be admitted that it is often overlooked by physicians without sufficient awareness of the disease.
Therefore, when treating patients with hepatic disorders and fatty liver disease, it is important to make a separate assessment regarding the possibility of Wilson's disease.

entities.name: hepatic disorders and fatty liver disease

text: Objective: From early 2019, sofosbuvir/velpatasvir (SOF/VEL) became available in Japan for the first time and can now be used to treat decompensated cirrhosis type C.

Although this will help more patients in their struggle to eliminate the virus, it will also require greater focus on the possibility of an adverse outcome during treatment due to the many complications of the disease.
The purpose of this study was to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy and safety of SOF/VEL in patients with decompensated liver cirrhosis type C being treated at our hospital.
Method: Study 6 patients diagnosed with decompensated cirrhosis type C, being treated with SOF/VEL, taking into consideration both the clinical background and course of treatment for each.
Distribution: 6 patients (2 male, 4 female) who were given SOF/VEL.
Median age at 68 years (range: 52-81).
All patients had Genotype 1b and no history of DAA treatment.

Prior to the taking of SOF/VEL, as per the Child-Pugh Criteria (CPS), 2 patients scored 7 points, 2 patients scored 10 points, 1 patient scored 11 points, and 1 patient scored 15 points as per the Child-Pugh Critera (CPS).
4 patients had previously been treated for liver cancer, and 2 patients had a history of esophageal varices prior to being given the new medication.
2 patients had a history of encephalopathy, and 5 patients had ascites prior to being given the medication.
All patients were treated under inpatient management.
During the course of treatment, three patients experienced a serious adverse outcome.
Case Report A: 56 year old male.
CPS at 10 points.
Esophageal varices had been noted 2 months before the start of treatment, but were left untreated.

entities.name: 2 months before the start of treatment

text: 4 weeks after starting the dosage of SOF/VEL, his esophageal varices ruptured.
Hemostatsis therapy was started and on the same day and the medication was discontinued.
3 weeks after starting the dosage, the HCV RNA PCR test trended towards negative, but relapsed 6 weeks after the medication had been discontinued.

entities.name: 6 weeks after the medication had been discontinued

text: Case Report B: 81 year old female CPS score at 10 points.
The patient had a previous history of first degree atrioventricular block, but no abnormalities were found on the echocardiograph.
The patient developed septicemia proximately caused by cellulitis on the day she started taking the SOF/VEL.
2 days after starting the medication, the eGFR level decreased to 29.03 and sinus arrest presented on the same day.
Medication was stopped and the following day the sinus arrest was less pronounced.
Case Report C: 52 year old female, CPS score at 15 points.
There was a history of hepatic encephalopathy.
The patient suffered from chronic renal failure range: stage 3b.
After one week of taking SOF/VEL the patient developed grade IV hepatic encephalopathy.
However, after fluid replacement, the patient showed signs of improvement by the next day, so the medication was continued.
Afterwards, the patient developed a tendency to retain fluid, as well as developing atrial fibrillation in the third week, which led to heart failure, but improved with the use of diuretics.
However, the eGFR gradually decreased over the course of treatment and in the 6th week with the eGFR dropping to 19.3 we decided to terminate the medication.
10 days after discontinuing SOF/VEL, the patient progressed to liver failure with death occurring 16 days after the discontinuation of SOF/VEL.
Except for one patient for whom treatment was discontinued an early stage, 5 patients tested negative for HCV RNA PCR, and 2 patients who completed the course of treatment achieved SVR4.

Conclusion: Although SOL/VEL has a high antiviral effect, patients with decompensated cirrhosis are prone to changes in the nature of their disease during treatment and close attention must be paid while following their progress during the course of treatment.
In particular, inpatient management is desirable in the early stage of medication.

entities.name: in the early stage of medication

text: Background: Helicobacter cinaedi (H. cinaedi) is a gram-negative helical rod bacterium that was discovered in the 1980s.
This bacteria inhabits both the intestine and liver.
It has been isolated from intestine and liver blood samples of patients who are immuno compromised, either due to some underlying disease or a course of chemotherapy.
Here, we report a case of H. cinaedi bacteremia and cellulitis associated with decompensated cirrhosis.
Case Report: 61-year-old male with decompensated cirrhosis, type C.
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of refractory hepatic ascites, with an objective to control the ascites.
The day before admission, the patient had presented brownish vomit in addition to having anemia (level at Hb 7.4 g/dl).
With the objective of performing a thorough examination an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was undertaken.
As a result, although no active bleeding was observed, the patient did have reflux esophagitis LA classification Grade C, and bleeding from the same site was suspected.
After resumption of food intake the patient no longer vomited, but due to a decreased level of food intake the hypoalbuminemia progressed and the ascites again worsened.
The ascites did not improve with the administration of furosemide and spironolactone, so that tolvaptan (3.75 mg/day) was started on the 7th day.
On the 9th day, the patient developed a fever of 38°C, although without any physical symptoms.
The fever continued intermittently until the 14th day, and on the 15th day, symptoms of bilateral lower leg pain, redness, warm sensations and swelling emerged.

entities.name: bilateral lower leg pain, redness, warm sensations and swelling

text: A MRI of the lower leg showed high signal intensity on the T2WI along the fascia of both lower legs, and a diagnosis was reached of cellulitis.

entities.name: along the fascia of both lower legs

text: Blood cultures were taken on the 11th, 13th, and 15th days, counting from the onset of the illness, to determine the causative organism, with H.

entities.name: 11th, 13th, and 15th days, counting from the onset of the illness

text: cinaedi being found in all cases.
The time it took to achieve positive blood culture ranged from 113 to 150 hours.
Ceftriaxone (2 g/day), which was started on the 15th day of the illness, was continued for treating bacteremia and cellulitis, both of which are caused by the same organism.
Since the patient's symptoms had improved his medication was switched to minocycline (200 mg/day) on the 29th day of the illness, and he was discharged on the 36th day of the illness.
Discussion: In many cases, H. cinaedi infection is detected in a blood culture taken from patients who have either cellulitis or proctitis.

However, an extended culture period of 5 to 7 days, or in some cases more than 10 days, is required to achieve a positive culture finding, and in some cases the culture may not prove positive within the normal incubation period.
Thus, if this organism is suspected, an extended time to process the blood culture should be requested.
Additionally, this infection has a high tendency to recur due to nosocomial infection or horizontal transmission,as has been reported in the literature.

text: In cases of biliary atresia, intractable and massive gastrointestinal bleeding is an important indication for liver transplant, even for patients who have yet to present liver failure.

Of the 1,411 patients who were given a liver transplant at our hospital, from June 1990 to the end of August 2010, 550 had biliary atresia, of which 136 had gastrointestinal bleeding, an indication that a liver transplant might be necessary.
Of these, the 26 patients who were given a liver transplant within one month, due to uncontrollable bleeding, are the focus of this report.
Patients' ages ranged from 8 months to 14 years, 8 months (mean 4 years, 2 months) with the male to female ratio at 10:16.

Hemorrhagic site-based classification of the cases is as follows: small bowel hemorrhage for 10 of the patients, rupture of gastroesophageal varices for 6 of the patients, hemorrhage from both sides for 6 of the patients, and indeterminate hemorrhagic site for 4 of the patients.

Introduction: In Japan living donor transplants are generally confined to patients who are post puberty, who have been carrying on with their own liver,and for some patients who have reached adulthood without receiving a transplant, it can be said that although their lives are characterized by a significantly poor QOL, the disease has yet to prove fatal.
It is all of these factors that make it difficult to decide when is best to undergo a liver transplant.
In this study, a living donor liver transplant was undertaken for a 33-year-old female patient following surgery to relieve both biliary atresia and repeated episodes of cholangitis.
Case Study: Patient underwent a hepatoportoenterostomy at 98 days of age.

text: Although the patient's mother was a possible donor, she was 63 years old at the time and an age restriction could make it difficult for her to still be a donor if the decision was put off for any longer.
Furthermore, a liver M transplant could make it possible for the patient to have children of her own.
With these factors in mind, we presented the option of a living donor liver transplant to the patient and her family.
At the mutual request of the patient and her family, a living donor liver transplant was performed approximately 6 months later.
On the second day after the transplant operation the patient required reanastomosis due to decreased hepatic artery blood flow, but progressed smoothly thereafter and is now 7 months post-transplant.

Conclusion: Although the objective is to improve the QOL for an adult patient, the indications for a living donor liver transplant are complicated, given that the lifestyle and circumstances of each patient are different and must be taken into account.
Hence it is difficult to standardize the decision criteria.

Many patients have adjusted to living with a chronic disease, which makes it difficult for them to reach a decision as to when to undergo a liver transplant; thus it is important for medical professionals, at the earliest opportunity, to provide medical advice vis-a-vis a liver transplant.
Here we report a case of a female patient in her 20s suffering from chronic biliary atresia, which she had from childhood, and who became depressed and underwent psychiatric treatment.

When nutrition is infused through a gastrostomy tube, the infusion rate is generally limited due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), diarrhea, other.

Since the patient may have to be restrained for lengthy periods of time,  and given that the infusion has to performed several times a day, this puts a considerable burden on both the patient and his caregivers.
Here we report on how the use of a gelatinized nutritional agent (one-shot infusion) resulted in improvement as the restraint time was shortened.
Furthermore, the risk level of gastrostomy complications was lowered.

The infant developed dumping syndrome, but improved after the nutritional supplement(s) had been gelatinized.
In both cases, the injection restraint time was shortened by the use of a one-shot injection.
Discussion: In adult patients the infusion of gelatinized nutrition is widespread.
In this  case we found that even for a 12-month-old infant, with a small stomach and narrow gastrostomy tube, it was possible to administer a one-shot infusion of gelatinized nutritional supplements.

Here we report a case of a pediatric patient who proved refractory to intravenous CsA therapy, yet whose condition improved with the introduction of intravenous FK506 therapy.

After a month of treatment, the score improved by 3 to 4 points, but oral intake proved difficult, and with convulsions presenting it was decided to switch the child to a continuous intravenous infusion of FK506.

text: The Department of Pediatric Surgery at our hospital provides nutritional guidance to children with chronic constipation.
