Rationale: (1) HHV-6 DNA was detected in the lesion.
(2) Another relapse occurred during tapering, which was rapid, of the steroid dosage.
Conclusion: 1) The onset of HS took place during the administration of carbamazepine.
2) Another relapse occurred during tapering of the steroid dosage.
(3) During the course of the disease, bronchiolitis was observed, but it disappeared with the improvement of HS.

(4) HS is often associated with multiple organ involvement such as the liver, however bronchial involvement is rare, but there have been reports of cases with only lymphadenopathy without skin symptoms, making it a disease with diverse systemic organ involvement.
In recent years there have been reports of the drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS) being triggered by reactivation of the herpesvirus family.
Here we report a case of carbamazepine (CBZ) induced HS in a juvenile who presented both HHV-6 reactivation and transient hypogammaglobulinemia.
Case Report: 14 year old male.
Chief Complaint: Fever, generalized erythema.
Past Medical History: Mild Intellectual Disability.
Current Medical History: In April 2001 the patient was having epileptic seizures and the administration of valproic acid (VPA) was started on April 20.
Subsequently, due to it becoming difficult to control the patient's convulsions, concomitant use of CBZ was started on July 6.
On July 23, fever and erythema presented, Subsequently, liver dysfunction and thrombocytopenia were also observed.
The patient was admitted and seen at our department on August 3.
He presented with facial edema, lymphadenopathy coupled with downward trending lab results.
Lab Results upon Admission: WBC 31,700/μL (eosinol%, A-ly 12.5% ), Plt 169,000/μL, TP 5.2 g/dL, AST I371 U/L, ALT 2021 U/L, LDH 7141 U/L, CRP 1.8 mg/dL, slL-2R 13,100 U/mL, 2-5AS  213 pMol/dL.
Progress: The antiepileptic drug CBZ was discontinued with VPA alone being administered.
mPSL pulse therapy was given for 3 days and the fever resolved.
Symptoms and lab results also improved.
Follow-up treatment started with 30 mg/day of PSL, but because fever and skin rash once again presented the medication was changed to 8 mg/day of betamethasone.
Subsequently, his symptoms both diminished and lightened, so that he could be discharged on August 20.
The patient's course of steroid treatment was completed 1 month after being discharged.
Since then until the present a relapse has not been observed.
The DLST for CBZ was positive with CBZ considered the causative agent.
HHV-61gG antibodies increased from 20 to 10, 240x, but there was no increase in the IgM level.
Real-time PCR of peripheral whole blood HHV-6 showed a decrease from 3.5 × 105 to 6.3 × 103 copies/106 cells during the course of treatment, confirming reactivation.
When admitted, the patient also had transient hypogammaglobulinemia.
Furthermore, at the time of admission, analysis of serum cytokines showed an increase in IL-5, IL-6, and IFN-g, which normalized after treatment.
Although DIHS is a rare disease, it is serious and needs to be diagnosed and treated as quickly as possible.
It is hoped that the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of HS will be further elucidated in the future, including its association with specific viral reactivation.

Case Report: 12-month-old infant boy.
Past Medical History: Micrognathia, dysphagia, developmental disability, developmental delay, gastroesophageal reflux disease and recurrent bacterial infection.
Lab Results: Eosinophil count: 3663/μ1, IgE 12.38 U/ml, RAST: milk 24.30 U/ml, soybean 1.22 U/ml, positive for eosinophils in stool.
Clinical Course: Since birth, the infant had been given milk by injecting it through a gastric tube due to dysphagia.
Intractable vomiting presenting from around the age of 13 months.
Given that his GER was getting worse, PPIs were tried but did not prove effective.
Because of the high eosinophil count, and taking his milk allergy into account, the infant was switched to a highly hydrolyzed formula, and his symptoms improved.
However, because of persistent nausea, the infant was switched to amino acid non-allergenic milk (Elental®P), but even so the vomiting grew worse again.
For this reason, the infant was changed from tube feeding to central venous feeding.
The symptoms, although mild, proved persistent.
A gastric biopsy showed eosinophilic infiltration, and eosinophilic gastroenteritis was the diagnosis reached.
Taking into consideration that the contamination of soy protein in fatty preparations could be the causative agent, the preparation was discontinued and, as a result, the symptoms disappeared.
Subsequently, tube feeding of soy-free amino acid non-allergenic milk (Elemental Formula) was initiated and no recurrence of the symptoms was observed.
Summary: This case of eosinophilic gastroenteritis, which we treated, was probably caused by milk and soy ingestion.
There have been few reports of an allergic reaction to soybean protein in fat preparations, and to our knowledge, no case of eosinophilic gastroenteritis has been reported to date.
Objective: The number of bronchial asthma attack cases visiting the emergency room (ER) is still not small.
We investigated cases of bronchial asthma attacks admitted from the ER of our hospital.

Method: We retrospectively analyzed patients who were admitted to the hospital after visiting the ER for bronchial asthma attacksin 2007, according to whether or not they had regular visits to the hospital, the medical institution they usually visited, and the medication they received before admission.

Results: Forty-four patients were hospitalized during the period, of whom 22.7% were admitted to our hospital, 56.8% to other hospitals, and 20.5% did not have a family doctor, regardless of whether they were regular or irregular.
Forty-one percent of patients were treated with inhaled steroids (ICS), 13% with oral therapy, and 46% with no treatment or SABA alone.
The mean hospital stay was 9 days.
ICS was introduced in all patients at the time of discharge.
Conclusion: More than half of the patients admitted to our hospital were not using ICS, and many of them were treated by general practitioners and frequently visited the ER.

Conclusion: The prevalence of ICS is still not high, and it is necessary to raise awareness of the importance of ICS in bronchial asthma throughout the community and to provide sufficient patient education.
Objective: The number of cases of bronchial asthma attacks visiting the emergency room (ER) has been decreasing compared with the past, but is still not small.
We investigated the trend of patients with bronchial asthma attacks visiting our ER.

Subjects and Methods: We retrospectively analyzed whether or not patients visited the ER for bronchial asthma attacks in 2007, including whether or not they had regular visits, their usual treatment, and the medical institutions they visited.
Results: A total of 417 patients visited the ER, with a mean age of 41.9 years.
The total percentage of patients with regular and irregular visits to our hospital was 40.4%, while 39.2% of patients visited a local doctor.
Patients with no family doctor made up 20.4%.
The percentage of patients with regular visits to our hospital and to local doctors was 58% and 26%, respectively.
ICS was used in 39.6% of cases, and SABA abortive use only, without ICS, was used in 22% of cases.
Conclusion: Many patients who visit the ER are still not treated with ICS.
On the other hand, there are many patients who visit the ER frequently, and it is necessary to promote the use of ICS in the entire region.

Conclusions: ICS did not significantly improve △FEV1 and FeNO in this patient with exercise-induced airway stenosis, suggesting that inhaled antihistamines, anti-LT and anticholinergics are effective.

A 60-year-old female.
Hay fever symptoms and throat discomfort after ingestion of fruits appeared in spring and early summer for several years.
About one year before the initial diagnosis, the patient was able to consume ordinary tofu but began to feel throat discomfort only when consuming oboro tofu or yuba.

entities.name: About one year before the initial diagnosis

text: She used to drink soy milk without any abnormality, but has not drunk soy milk since the onset of symptoms caused by oboro tofu and yuba.
Specific IgE was class 5 positive in birch and alder, class 3 positive in peach and apple, class 2 positive in strawberry, and class 1 positive in soybeans.
The prick test was (3+) positive in soy milk and soybeans, and (2+) positive in oboro tofu, yuba, and tofu.
Therefore, we diagnosed our patient as allergic to tofu caused by the mechanism of OAS.
In recent years, there have been many reports of cases of soy milk allergy, but almost all cases are able to consume regular tofu.
The only difference in composition between soy milk and tofu is the bittern content.

However, the difference in antigenicity between the two has been speculated to be due to the fact that soy milk is in a solution state and is more easily absorbed from the oral mucosa than tofu, resulting in OAS.
We thought that the results of our own study, in which the symptoms occurred only when taking oboro tofu and yuba, which are more watery than regular tofu, supported such a hypothesis.
Objective: The purpose of this study is to determine the diagnosis, pathogenesis, and treatment of a case of recurrent eruption coinciding with the bathing area while taking a bath.
Method: The patient is a 74-year-old male.
Five years ago, the patient became aware of a swelling rash that coincided with the bathing area and the contact area of the heating seat.
A blood test, intradermal test of Ovisot, noradrenaline, and autologous serum at room temperature and at room temperature after heating, ice cube test, and heat stress test were performed.
Results: Peripheral blood, biochemical tests, immunoglobulin, and serum complement titer were within the standard values, and autoantibodies were negative.
Serum total IgE was 88.41 U/ml, and specific IgE was positive only for Anisakis as class 2.
After contacting the skin with a beaker heated to 45°C for 5 minutes as a heat stress test, a localized swelling rash was observed in the same area.
In addition, no puffiness appeared in 38°C water, puffiness appeared after 5 minutes in 40°C water, and puffiness appeared immediately after in 42°C water.

Conclusions: The sweating caused by exercise did not produce a swelling rash, and the negative intradermal test of Ovisot ruled out cholinergic reed measles, and the negative intradermal test of noradrenaline ruled out adrenergic reed measles.

Water reed measles were ruled out by the negative result of the warm water bath at 38°C, cold reed measles were ruled out by the negative result of the ice cube test, and warm reed measles were diagnosed by the positive result of the heat stress test.

Intradermal tests were performed on autologous serum immediately after it had been heated from no heating to 42°C for 15 min, to 60°C for 15 min, and then returned to room temperature, and on serum stored at room temperature for 4 h after heating.
Both test results were negative.

text: The patient was treated conservatively with antibiotics for acute appendicitis, and was referred to the Department of Gastroenterology for preoperative evaluation and admission.

Twenty-five days after referral from the previous physician, the patient underwent laparoscopic ileal resection on suspicion of appendiceal cancer.
Histopathological findings were adenocarcinoma, MP, N0, M0, Stage I, and the appendix had findings of catarrhal appendicitis.
He was discharged from the hospital on the 10th day without any postoperative problems, and is currently in the outpatient clinic without any recurrence for 12 months after the surgery.

It is relatively rare to find appendiceal carcinoma in patients with acute appendicitis, and as far as we could find, this would be the 34th case as there have been 23 reports of 33 cases in Japan between 1991 and 2012.

Objective: To report a case in which NST intervention significantly improved the nutritional status of a patient with advanced rectal cancer who was severely malnourished.
Case Report: A 55-year-old male.
Medical history: He has always been a picky eater.
The patient had diarrhea for 2 years, worsened dysgeusia and anorexia for 2 months, and could not take anything but water for 5 days when he visited our hospital.
The patient was diagnosed with highly advanced rectal cancer and underwent a colostomy, but due to prolapse of the colostomy, an emergency Hartmann operation was performed.

TPN management was performed until the improvement of postoperative peritonitis, and the patient started eating on the 9th postoperative day, but the intake was insufficient due to taste disorder and anorexia, and NST intervention was performed on the 10th postoperative day.
At the time of intervention, the patient was 173 cm tall, 46 kg in weight, 2.7 g/dl Alb, 8.1 g/dl Hb, and had moderate nutritional impairment.

On the same day nasogastric tube was inserted and synbiotics (EN) were continuously administered to restore intestinal function, and then the dose was increased and continued until the watery stools stopped.
The dosage was increased step by step from the 19th day after normal stool, and the nutritional requirements were met on the 21st day.

With the improvement of dysgeusia, the patient started oral intake in small amounts from the 26th day of illness, and because dysgeusia almost disappeared on the 33rd day of illness, the patient was switched to a personalized diet that took preferences into consideration, and EN was completely discontinued on 53rd day of illness.
The intervention was terminated after confirming improvement in nutritional status and ADL on the 75th day of sickness.

Discussion: We believe that the NST intervention contributed to the improvement of the nutritional status and ADL by providing appropriate nutritional administration methods, selection of nutritional supplements, preference-conscious meals, and rehabilitation.
Case Report: 66-year-old male, 170 cm, 48 kg, BMI 16.6 kg/m2.

Our NSTs maintain and improve the oral environment by taking dental approaches such as oral care and denture adjustment in order to shift the route of nutritional administration to oral and improve eating patterns.

In addition, pregabalin 150 mg/day was started for brachial plexus infiltration syndrome.

Nine days after the start of the treatment, rapid deterioration of renal function and ureteral stent obstruction were observed, and a right nephrostomy was immediately constructed and pregabalin was discontinued.
With improvement of renal function, myoclonus disappeared 2 days after discontinuation of pregabalin, but emotional incontinence was observed.

In this case, the blood concentration of pregabalin fluctuated due to changes in renal function caused by urinary tract obstruction and patency, and these adverse events were thought to have appeared.
Conclusion: We experienced an appearance of myoclonus and emotional incontinence associated with changes in renal function after the atomisation of pregabalin.
Pregabalin is renally excreted, and caution should be exercised as unexpected side effects may occur when renal function deteriorates.

Furthermore, after healing of the IP, a small bowel perforation occurred, requiring emergency surgery.
The patient had a good postoperative course, but the tumor grew rapidly and he died 8 months after the first treatment.

In this case, the patient was refractory to primary therapy but responded to secondary therapy.

However, in the course of treatment, the patient developed IP and small bowel perforation, which prevented adequate anticancer drug therapy, and the immunosuppressive state caused by steroid therapy for IP may have shortened the survival period.
If these events had not occurred, it is possible that the patient could have benefited from anticancer therapy.
Although there are some reports of poor prognosis in the non-MSI group of patients with BRAF mutations, our results suggest that the MSI group may respond to treatment.
Case report of a 54-year-old male patient Pre-existing allergic rhinitis.
He visited our clinic in December 2010 for right lower abdominal pain.
Blood pressure was 126/76 mm Hg, pulse rate was 77 beats/min, and body temperature was 36.9°C.
Tenderness and recoil pain were noted around McBurney's point, and blood samples showed an elevated white blood cell count of 11,000 mm3 (75% neutrophils, 1% eosinophils) and CRP of 2.08 mg/dl.
On abdominal CT, thickening of the appendiceal wall and elevation of the surrounding lipid tissue concentration were observed, and acute appendicitis was suspected.
On the other hand, appendiceal or cecal cancer could not be ruled out because wall thickening was observed up to the cecum.
An emergency laparotomy was performed to find an enlarged appendix and a hard mass lesion of about 50 mm in the appendix.
An ileocecum resection was performed.
The resected specimen suggested cellulitis appendicitis, but in addition, there was a 50 x 30 mm ulcerative lesion near the appendiceal orifice, the submucosa of which was elastic hard.
Pathological results showed an eosinophilic inflammatory cell infiltrate with increased fibrous connective tissue in the submucosal to subplasmalemmal tissues of the cecum.

In the appendix as well as in the cecum, fibrous connective tissue was observed in the submucosa and appendiceal mesentery, and an inflammatory cell infiltrate consisting mainly of eosinophils and a neutrophil infiltrate was observed.
Based on the results, the diagnosis of eosinophilic colitis of the cecum to the appendix with cellulitis acute appendicitis was made.
In this report, we describe a rare case of eosinophilic colitis involving the cecum and appendix, with a review of the literature.

text: There was localized tenderness and recurrent pain in the left lower abdomen, but no muscular defenses were present.

CT showed inflammatory images and freeAir around the sigmoid colon, so blood transfusion was started and emergency surgery was performed.
When the abdomen was opened, a perforation of the sigmoid colon was observed, and the perforation site was dissected and a colostomy was performed.
The cause of the perforation was thought to be a sigmoid colon ulcer, and multiple ulcers were also identified in the raised colonic mucosa.
There was a possibility of multiple ulcers in the remaining intestine, and CMV enteritis during long-term steroid therapy was raised as a differential diagnosis.
CMV antigenemia could not be measured due to the end of the year, but treatment including ganciclovir administration was initiated.
On the fourth day of treatment, CMV antigenemia was measured and the cell count was positive, although it was small, and ganciclovir was continued for 3 weeks.
Pathological findings also confirmed CMV inclusion bodies, and a final diagnosis of CMV enteritis was made.
Summary: It is important to keep CMV enteritis in mind when treating gastrointestinal perforations in immunosuppressed patients.

text: A pyloric gastrectomy with a D3 resection was performed as an adjuvant surgery.
The pathological examination shows L, Less, yType3, ypT2, int, INFb, v1, ly3, ypN2, M0, P0, CY0, H0, ypStage IIB, pPM0, pDM0, pR0, Grade2.
No metastasis was found in the enlarged para-aortic lymph node.
After surgery, S-1 was administered as adjuvant therapy for 1 year, and the patient has been the attending outpatient clinic without recurrence for 2 years after surgery.

The average life expectancy of patients with unresectable advanced gastric cancer treated with S-1/CDDP is reported to be about 13 months, but many cases of long-term survival have been reported in patients who underwent radical resection by downstaging.
In this study, we report a case of recurrence-free survival after 2 years of S-1/CDDP therapy for unresectable advanced gastric cancer.
The patient is a 59-year-old female.
She visited her local doctor with a chief complaint of bloody discharge.
She had a history of total hysterectomy for uterine fibroids 20 years ago.
On vaginal speculum examination, a tumor was found at the vaginal margin, and a biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma.
Lower gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a circumferential type 2 tumor in the sigmoid colon, which was biopsied and diagnosed as a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma.
CEA was found to be elevated at 61 ng/ml.
Abdominal CT showed a tumor of 48 mm in diameter in the sigmoid colon, with extensive direct invasion of the bladder and vaginal margins, and metastasis to lymph node 253 and the left side.

entities.name: metastasis to lymph node 253 and the left side

text: Sigmoid colon cancer,cSI(bladder, vagina)　cN3, cH0, cP0, cM1 (#283), cStage lV has been diagnosed.

The patient was treated with mFOLFOX6 as preoperative chemotherapy for a total of seven courses over a period of about six months after a transverse colon twin-hole colostomy was performed because curative resection was judged to be difficult.
As a result of chemotherapy, CEA decreased to 15 ng/ml, and abdominal CT showed a marked reduction in tumor size.
cSI(the bladder) remained although tumor invasion into the vagina disappeared.
The left lateral lymph node metastasis also disappeared.
The surgery was performed because the down staging was obtained to cH0, cP0, cM0, cStage ll.
Surgery included resection of the sigmoid colon, total cystectomy, combined vaginal dissection, and lateral lymph node dissection, which resulted in curative resection.
There is currently no consensus on the efficacy of preoperative chemotherapy for highly advanced colorectal cancer in Japan.
In this report, we describe a case of highly advanced sigmoid colon cancer that was curatively resectable with preoperative chemotherapy with downstaging and sufficient surgical margin.
The patient is a 14-year-old female.
Bowel endoscopy revealed a circumferential type 3 tumor in the lower rectum 3 cm from the anal verge, and biopsy revealed a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.

entities.name: lower rectum 3 cm from the anal verge

text: There was no significant family history of disease.
MRI showed an irregular wall thickening of the rectum Rb-Ra of 76 mm in size, suggesting lymph node metastasis in the mesorectum and along the left internal iliac artery, but no distant metastasis.

entities.name: in the mesorectum and along the left internal iliac artery

text: This was a preoperative diagnosis of cStage3b.
Prior to treatment, bilateral ovarian arterioles and admixtures were given laparoscopically, and the ovaries were fixed to the abdominal wall of the irradiation field.
After executing preoperative chemoradiation (50.4 Gy/28 Fr, weekly 5-FU/OHP), the patient underwent low anterior rectal resection with upper D3 and left lateral dissection.

entities.name: upper D3 and left lateral dissection

text: Pathological diagnosis was as follows,pA, pN1 (2/18), fStage 3a.
One year has passed since the surgery, and the patient is alive without recurrence.

entities.name: One year has passed since the surgery

text: When rectal cancer is treated with preoperative radiation therapy, the loss of ovarian function associated with treatment is not only a problem of loss of fertility but also a problem of spiritual pain for women.
Ovarian mobilization and fixation has been adapted in the field of gynecology as far as it did not reduce the probability of successful treatment.
However, in colorectal cancer, the ovary is not resectable unless there is direct invasion or metastasis, and laparoscopic ovarian mobilization and fixation may be considered in younger patients.
Chemotherapy for advanced recurrent colorectal cancer has made remarkable progress in recent years and is widely used in Japan, especially FOLFOX therapy.
Recently, mFOLFOX6 and Xelox therapy have been introduced as adjuvant therapy after curative resection.
We introduced mFOLFOX6 as preoperative systemic chemotherapy to improve the prognosis of locally advanced rectal cancer and have obtained good results.
In this report, we describe a case of postoperative pCR.
The patient is a 62-year-old male.
In May 2012, diarrhea appeared, and in July, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting appeared, leading to a visit to our clinic.
Abdominal radiography showed colonic gas with dilatation, and abdominal CT scan showed thickening of the rectal wall.
The patient was urgently admitted to the hospital with a suspected colonic ileus caused by rectal cancer, and a transanal ileus tube was inserted.

entities.name: colonic ileus caused by rectal cancer

text: On lower gastrointestinal endoscopy (CF), a circumferential mass was found in the rectum about 6 cm from the anal verge, and the fiber could not be passed.

entities.name: rectum about 6 cm from the anal verge

text: Adenocarcinoma was diagnosed by biopsy, and rectal cancer (Ra), T3, N2, HO, PO, and MO cStageIIIb were also diagnosed.

After the surgery  of ileal colostomy and 6 courses of mFOLFOX6 therapy, CT scan of the abdomen showed that the primary tumor had shrunk by more than 70%, and regional lymph nodes also tended to shrink.
The CF showed only scarring stenosis.
After a 4-week withdrawal period from the last dose, the patient underwent laparoscopic low anterior resection.
Gross examination of the excised specimen revealed only scar stenosis and smooth mucosal surface.
Pathology results showed that the histological effects were grade 3.
The results of pCR were obtained, showing no cancer tissue.
Introduction: We report the case of a young female who underwent IVR followed by a small laparotomy for gastrointestinal bleeding due to abnormal small bowel vessels.
Case Report: 27-year-old female.
No history of disease.
In December 2012, the patient was brought to our emergency room with severe abdominal pain and rectal bleeding.
Diagnosis of small bowel hemorrhage by contrast-enhanced CT abdomen.
The patient was in hemorrhagic shock at the time of admission and was transfused with 8 units of concentrated red blood cells.
Urgent IVR was performed to find the source of bleeding and to control hemostasis.
The ruptured vessel and the surrounding jejunum (approximately 10 cm) were embolized with microcoils, cyanoacrylate, and lipiodol.
Immediately afterwards, an emergency partial resection of the small bowel was performed.
A small 4 cm laparotomy was performed and the responsible lesion was identified using intraoperative fluoroscopy.
The lesion was located 150 cm from the Treitz ligament and 440 cm from the terminal ileum, and a partial jejunal resection of approximately 8 cm was performed.

entities.name: 150 cm from the Treitz ligament and 440 cm from the terminal ileum

text: The postoperative course was good and the patient was discharged on the 10th day after surgery.
Pathology results showed only a few abnormal vessels in the small intestine.
Conclusion: Small bowel hemorrhage is a relatively rare disease, and the lesion is often difficult to identify.
It is impossible to identify the lesion intraoperatively, especially when the lesion is small, as in this case.
Hemostasis and marking by IVR is a useful method for diagnosis and treatment with a small laparotomy and minimal resection.
The patient is 64 years old, male.
He was admitted to a psychiatric hospital for schizophrenia, and was referred to our hospital for fever, abdominal distension, and vomiting.
Upon admission, he was positive for influenza A and had mild abdominal tenderness, but his white blood cell count was 7500/μl and CRP was 18.0 mg/dl, indicating an increased inflammatory response.
There were findings of a mobile appendix on CT, and an adhesive ileus due to the appendix was suspected at the slightly oral part of the ileum.

entities.name: slightly oral part of the ileum

text: Since the inflammation was localized and the intestinal blood flow was maintained, conservative treatment with insertion of an ileus tube was started.

entities.name: conservative treatment with insertion of an ileus tube

text: However, the patient did not improve even on the third sick day, and emergency surgery was performed because it was judged that the patient was in a state of complete obstruction.
On opening the abdomen, the appendix was fibrously adherent to the ileum about 3 cm from the terminal ileum, forming a band and strangulating the ileum.

entities.name: ileum about 3 cm from the terminal ileum

text: When the band was removed, the color tone of the intestine was good and only a removal of appendix was performed.
Histological examination of the resected specimens showed no malignant findings in acute appendicitis.
The patient had a good postoperative course and was discharged on the seventh postoperative day, with no recurrence of ileus to date.
Although preoperative paralytic ileus and postoperative adhesive ileus have been experienced as complications of appendicitis, case reports of strangulated ileus are rare.
We report a case of strangulated ileus due to appendiceal adhesions, including some discussion of the literature.
We report a case of idiopathic retroperitoneal hematoma diagnosed histologically by laparoscopic removal of a retroperitoneal mass discovered incidentally during removal of gallbladder.
Case Report: The patient was a 50-year-old male who was diagnosed with gallbladder stones during a physical examination and came to our department for surgery.
He had no specific symptoms and no history of abdominal trauma.
Abdominal ultrasonography showed gallbladder stones and a well-defined mass of 4 cm in diameter between the liver and the right kidney.

entities.name: between the liver and the right kidney

text: The mass was also seen on CT scan to drain the inferior vena cava ventrally and the right adrenal gland cephalad.
Based on the above, the preoperative diagnosis of gallbladder stone disease and retroperitoneal tumor was made.

entities.name: gallbladder stone disease and retroperitoneal tumor

text: Initially, the patient requested only removal of gallbladder, so a single-hole laparoscopic cholecystectomy was performed.
Furthermore, one and a half months after the surgery, the patient requested retroperitoneal tumor resection, which was performed laparoscopically.

entities.name: one and a half months after the surgery

text: The mass was smooth-surfaced and elastic-hard.
Histologically, it was diagnosed as a hematoma because it was surrounded by a thick fibrous membrane in a circumferential fashion and the interior consisted of blood and unstructured material.

entities.name: surrounded by a thick fibrous membrane

text: Conclusion: Histologically, various tumors rarely occur in the retroperitoneum, and the probability of malignancy is high.
However, there are few specific findings in clinical symptoms and imaging studies, and histological examination by biopsy is also difficult.
Histological study by laparoscopic excision is a less invasive and useful examination and treatment method.

Subjects, Methods: Twenty-one patients with uric acid-containing stones of the upper urinary tract at the Department of Urology, Teikyo University Ichihara Hospital from May 1986 to October 1990 were included in this study, and their cases were examined mainly by biochemical tests.
Serum uric acid levels and urinary biochemistry were compared with those of normal subjects and calcium stone patients.
Results: Serum uric acid level and daily uric acid excretion were significantly higher in patients with pure uric acid stones than in healthy subjects.
Urinary Mg excretion was lower in patients with mixed uric acid and Ca stones than in healthy subjects.

entities.name: mixed uric acid and Ca stones

text: In comparison with Ca stone patients, only serum uric acid level was higher in uric acid stone patients, and uric acid clearance and FEurate were significantly higher in Ca stone patients than in healthy subjects.
Uric acid excretion function was aggravated in the kidneys of patients with Ca stones.
It is assumed that these points are related to the formation of stones.
Objective: Nephrectomy was performed through a two lateral finger (4 cm) incision for a large hydronephrosis with thinning of the parenchyma.
The endoscope was inserted through the wound, and the nephrectomy was performed in the following order.
Except for the ligature, normal surgical instruments were used.
(1) A two lateral finger skin incision was added to the tip of the 12th rib in the nephrectomy position, and the muscle layer was only divided (Vexel).
(2) The tip of the 12th rib was resected and entered the retroperitoneal cavity.
(3) The posterior lobe of the Gerota fascia was detached to reach the renal stalk.

entities.name: posterior lobe of the Gerota fascia

text: (4) Ligation and amputation of the renal artery and vein.
(5) Secure the ureter and insert a neraton catheter through the cut end of the ureter to aspirate and remove urine from the renal mucosa (580 ml).
(6) The upper pole is detached at the renal fibrous capsule and nephrectomized with a closed wound.
In this case, we first searched for a lesion at the ureteric stenosis (vascular intersection) from the appendicectomy scar.
Results: (1) Operation time: 250 min.
Bleeding volume: 100 ml.
(2) There were no complications.
(3) The patient was able to eat and walk from the day after the surgery.
(4) All participants in the surgery were able to observe the deep manipulation.
Discussion: Transumbilical nephrectomy through a small specular incision was considered to be a minimally invasive and safe method even for large hydronephrosis.

entities.name: Transumbilical nephrectomy through a small specular incision

text: Objective: We report our experience with transurethral enucleation with bipolar (TUEB) using a bipolar system, a minimally invasive procedure for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
Target and Method: TUEB was introduced in our department in March 2008, and was performed in 23 patients with BPH until September 2008.
The patients' age ranged from 61 to 81 (mean age 68 years).
The preoperative PSA ranged from 2.2 to 20 ng/ml (mean 7.3 ng/ml).
Patients with a PSA of 4.0 ng/ml or higher underwent preoperative transrectal prostate biopsy to rule out cancer.
The estimated volume of the prostate measured by ultrasonography ranged from 36.4 to 124.6 ml (mean 74.1 ml).
Results: Since our department does not have a morcellator, all but three of the borrowed cases were removed with a loop electrode.
No cases required blood transfusion, and catheters were removed on postoperative days 2 to 5.
TUEB was evaluated preoperatively and at 3 months postoperatively by subjective symptom score, urine flow rate and residual urine measurement, and PSA measurement.

entities.name: urine flow rate and residual urine measurement

text: Objective: Evaluating the long-term effects of an initially temporary urethral stent on the urinary retention of elderly patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) during catheterization and reimplantation of a permanent urethral stent.
Target and Methods: The subjects were 23 men with benign prostatic hyperplasia.
Temporary urethral stents were Prostacus in 12 cases and Memokath in 11 cases.
The mean age at the deployment of temporary urethral stent placement was 80 years.
Urinary retention in all cases.
Permanent urethral stent: 83 years old at the time of re-implantation of the change to Memotherm.

entities.name: at the time of re-implantation of the change

text: Previous catheter life duration averaged 7 months.
The method was as follows: under local anesthesia, a temporary urethral stent was removed and a permanent urethral stent was implanted.
At 3 mm distal to the bladder neck, the handle was pulled several times to start releasing the stent and wait 2-3 minutes while infusing warm water.

entities.name: 3 mm distal to the bladder neck

text: The stent was then slowly opened and implanted 5 mm shorter than the measured value.
After the self-drainage test, a 14Fr, balloon catheter was indwelt for 3 days.
Results: All patients were able to urinate on their own.
MFR was 18.9 ml/sec, IPSS was 6, and QOL and ADL were improved.
It is over 10 years old and the permanent mold is still functioning well.

Discussion: Stents in urology started with Fabian's spiral type, but there were many inconveniences such as stone adhesion, difficulty in exchange and removal, migration, UTI, and difficulty in catheter reinsertion.
The device was changed and reimplantation was performed with an improved permanent-type device, which led to an adequate response to treatment using TUL and cystoscopy.
There has also been experience with a double stent.
Permanent urethral stents were also useful in the long term.
Targets and Methods: Five patients with both bladder cancer and lung cancer, who were histopathologically diagnosed as primary tumors at our hospital were selected.
Their background, diagnostic history, and histology were gathered.
Results 1: Four males and one female.
Four patients had a history of smoking.
There were 4 cases of prior bladder cancer and 1 case of prior lung cancer.

One patient was diagnosed during the treatment of a previous cancer, one patient was diagnosed during a medical checkup, and the other three patients visited the department directly after complaining of symptoms.
All bladder cancers were urothelial carcinoma, with 4 cases of non-muscle layer invasion and 1 case of invasion.
In lung cancer, squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma were detected in 2 cases each.
The remaining case is scheduled for surgery.
Bladder cancer was treated with TUR-Bt in 4 cases and total cystectomy in 1 case.
For lung cancer, there were 3 cases of surgery and 2 cases of inoperability.
Two patients died of lung cancer, one patient was cured of both bladder cancer and lung cancer, and one patient had no recurrence of bladder cancer, and lung cancer was in progress.
Discussion: In cancer patients, various examinations are performed, and it is not uncommon for other diseases to be detected incidentally during these examinations.
However, in the present study, there were three cases out of five in which the late-stage cancer had already become an advanced cancer despite regular visits to the hospital.
Because all prior cases of bladder cancer were non-muscle invasive cancer, chest CT scan was not performed.

Considering that the prognosis of lung cancer is generally severe, a chest CT scan should be performed in the follow-up of bladder cancer, especially in smokers and those with a history of other malignant tumors, even if complete cure is achieved.
The patient is a 20-year-old male.
On May 15, 2007, the patient presented to the emergency department with lightheadedness and gross hematuria.
The patient was admitted to the hospital as an emergency due to hemorrhagic shock just before inspection with CT.

entities.name: admitted to the hospital as an emergency

text: Abdominal pelvic CT showed a mass in the bladder.
On May 16, Doppler echocardiography showed blood flow in a mass in the bladder, and MRI showed a tumor in the hematoma, which was diagnosed as a bladder tumor.
Gross hematuria remained unchanged, and Ht remained unchanged in the 20% range even with blood transfusion.
On the same day, angiography was performed urgently from the major artery.
Two arteries branched from the left internal iliac artery and leading to the tumor in the bladder were found, and embolization was performed with Zelform.
Gross hematuria faded and TUR-Bt was performed on May 17.
A tumor of approximately 5 cm in size was observed from the apex of the bladder to the posterior wall.

entities.name: from the apex of the bladder to the posterior wall

text: The tumor was resected.
The weight of the excised specimen was 33 g.
Histopathology showed TCC, G1, pTa, and the clinical stage was pTa, N0, and M0.
Eight BCG intravesical injections were performed to prevent recurrence from June 29.
Now, one year and four months after surgery, no recurrence has been observed.

entities.name: one year and four months after surgery

text: Bladder cancer occurring in young people is a clinically rare disease.
In this article, we report a case of hemorrhagic shock caused by superficial bladder cancer in a 20-year-old male, with some discussion of the literature.
